titles.title: Isolating Sources of Ionization in Nearby Seyfert Galaxies

descriptions.description: We present an ongoing research effort to identify ionization sources in nearby AGN using Apache Point Observatory (APO) and the Hubble Space Telescope (HST). We measure emission line ratios along the spatial extents of the narrow line region (NLR) using spectra from APO's Dual Imaging Spectrograph (DIS) and HST's Space Telescope Imaging Spectrograph (STIS). The spectra reveal prominent emission lines of ionized gas that can be primarily attributed to star formation or AGN ionization. We construct BPT diagrams and compare with HST color images to isolate these regions and determine their connection to the kinematics of the outflowing gasses. When combined with our ongoing study of mass outflow rates, these efforts will help further our overall goal of determining the effectiveness of AGN feedback on their host galaxies. We present two targets: NGC 1667, a Seyfert 2 galaxy with observed redshift of z = 0.01517 (319 pc/"), and NGC 4051, a Seyfert 1 galaxy with z = 0.00234 (53 pc/"). Overlaid APO BPT diagrams correspond well to visual regions of star formation and AGN ionization displayed in the HST images. Identification of ionization mechanisms are consistent for the [N II], [S II], and [O I] ratios, providing confidence in our methodology.

We employ a multiple component Gaussian fitting routine (Fischer, T. C. et al. 2017, ApJ, 834, 30) to determine the wavelength centroid, width and peak flux of the strong [O III] emission lines gathered by DIS. We then use the resulting fit parameters as templates to obtain kinematics and flux ratios of all other lines and then separate components based on total flux. We construct BPT (Baldwin, Phillips & Terlevich 1981) diagrams by determining ratios of the [O III] λ5007/Hβ λ4861 lines and comparing them with the ratios of [N II] λ6584, [S II] λ6716, λ6731, and [O I] λ6300 to H-alpha λ6563 for each kinematic component. We use the equations of Kewley et al. (2006) to determine if the primary source of the ionizing radiation at each location in the narrow-line region (NLR) is due to the central AGN (Seyfert or LINER), star formation, or a mixture of both (composite). Finally we generate the BPT Diagrams for each slit position and utilize the ratio points and distance data to create ionization maps to overlay onto scaled HST images for visible comparison. APO's DIS observations (four position angles for NGC 4051 and three for NGC 1667) were taken using B/R1200 gratings (resolving power R ~ 2000) with slit width = 2". HST spectra were obtained from MAST archive.
Presented at the 2021 APO Science Symposium (APOSS21), virtual conference, July 26-28, 2021.

ast.title: Isolating Sources of Ionization in Nearby Seyfert Galaxies
ast.introduction: Emitted radiation from nearby active galaxies have shown to primarily be either the result of radiation from accretion disks around supermassive black holes at the center of AGN or the result of star formation in the host galaxy. We present two of our targets: NGC 1667, a Seyfert 2 galaxy with observed redshift of z = 0.01517 (319 pc/"), and NGC 4051, a Seyfert 1 galaxy with z = 0.00234 (53 pc/") (Verheijen & Sancisi, 2001). APO's DIS observations (four position angles for NGC 4051 and three for NGC 1667) were taken using B/R1200 gratings (resolving power R ~ 2000) with slit width = 2". HST spectra were obtained from MAST archive.
ast.methods: We employ a multiple component Gaussian fitting routine (Fischer, T. C. et al. 2017, ApJ, 834, 30) to determine the wavelength centroid, width and peak flux of the strong [O III] emission lines gathered by DIS. We then use the resulting fit parameters as templates to obtain kinematics and flux ratios of all other lines and then separate components based on total flux. Finally we generate the BPT Diagrams for each slit position and utilize the ratio points and distance data to create ionization maps to overlay onto scaled HST images for visible comparison. We construct BPT (Baldwin, Phillips & Terlevich 1981) diagrams by determining ratios of the [O III] λ5007/Hβ λ4861 lines and comparing them with the ratios of [N II] λ6584, [S II] λ6716, λ6731, and [O I] λ6300 to H-alpha λ6563 for each kinematic component. We use the equations of Kewley et al. (2006) to determine if the primary source of the ionizing radiation at each location in the narrow-line region (NLR) is due to the central AGN (Seyfert or LINER), star formation, or a mixture of both (composite). We add a colorbar to each BPT diagram to indicate distance from the center of the observed slit. Using the above data, we generate ionization maps to show the primary source of ionization of the brightest flux component along each position angle in the NLR and into the extended NLR (ENLR) within the host galaxy.
ast.results: Overlaid APO BPT diagrams correspond well to visual regions of star formation and AGN ionization displayed in the HST images (such as the star formation arm SW of the central AGN in NGC 4051). Identification of ionization mechanisms are consistent for the [N II], [S II], and [O I] ratios, providing confidence in our methodology. NGC 1667 displays BPT diagrams for three position angles (PA = 55°, 108°, 160°) showing high flux and low flux components as a function of distance from the nucleus. NGC 4051 displays BPT diagrams for three position angles (PA = 98°, 233°, 188°) with a fourth slit position angle at 143° not shown. The ionization maps show primary regional ionization mechanisms: star formation (blue), AGN ionization (red) and composite (green).
ast.conclusions: Additional work is needed to compare our ionization maps with spatially-resolved maps of the kinematics and mass-outflow rates generated by other members of our group. Similar overlays and analyses will be done for 6 additional Seyfert galaxies, including Mrk 78, NGC 1068, and Mrk 3 to compare spatially resolved mass outflow rates with the local ionization mechanisms.

contentArray.title1: Isolating Sources of Ionization in Nearby Seyfert Galaxies
contentArray.title2: Introduction: Emitted radiation from nearby active galaxies have shown to primarily be either the result of radiation from accretion disks around supermassive black holes at the center of AGN or the result of star formation in the host galaxy. We study NGC 1667 (Seyfert 2, z = 0.01517) and NGC 4051 (Seyfert 1, z = 0.00234) using Apache Point Observatory and Hubble Space Telescope observations.
contentArray.title3: Methodology: We employ multiple component Gaussian fitting to determine emission line parameters from APO's DIS spectra. We construct BPT diagrams using [O III]/Hβ versus [N II]/Hα, [S II]/Hα, and [O I]/Hα ratios to classify ionization sources as AGN (Seyfert or LINER), star formation, or composite. Ionization maps are overlaid on HST color images.
contentArray.title4: Results: BPT diagrams for NGC 1667 (PA = 55°, 108°, 160°) and NGC 4051 (PA = 98°, 233°, 188°, 143°) show high and low flux components. Overlaid maps correspond well to visual regions of star formation and AGN ionization in HST images. Ionization mechanisms are consistent across [N II], [S II], and [O I] ratios.
contentArray.title5: Future Work: Additional comparisons needed with spatially-resolved kinematics and mass-outflow rate maps. Similar analyses planned for 6 additional Seyfert galaxies including Mrk 78, NGC 1068, and Mrk 3 to compare spatially resolved mass outflow rates with local ionization mechanisms.

imageCaption.caption1: Figure 1: NGC 1667 HST color image with distance-based [N II] BPT overlay
imageCaption.caption2: An HST color image of NGC 1667 with a distance-based [N II] BPT overlaid on the nucleus. Displays primary regional ionization mechanisms: star formation (blue), AGN ionization (red) and composite (green). Photo courtesy of the Carnegie-Irvine Galaxy Survey. Scale: 0.5" ≈ 500 pc. Left panels show [N II] BPT diagrams for high flux (large squares) and low flux (small squares) components as function of distance from nucleus along APO DIS long-slit at PA = 55° (top), 108° (middle) and 160° (bottom).

imageCaption.caption1: Figure 2: NGC 4051 HST color image with [N II] BPT overlay
imageCaption.caption2: An HST color image of NGC 4051 with its [N II] BPT overlay. North is pointed toward 18°. Scale: 10". Right panels show [N II] BPT diagrams for high flux (large squares) and low flux (small squares) components as function of distance from nucleus along APO DIS long-slit at PA = 98° (top), 233° (middle) and 188° (bottom). BPT for fourth slit position angle 143° is not shown.

imageCaption.caption1: Figure 3: Example of two component Gaussian fit to [O III] emission line
imageCaption.caption2: Shows high flux component (blue), low flux component (red), and total fit (magenta) demonstrating the multiple component fitting routine used to determine wavelength centroid, width and peak flux.
